bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Ciaran Gerard Carson (1948-), Irish poet. He was born in Belfast on 9 October 1948. He attended St. Mary's Christian Brothers' School in Belfast before going on to Queen's University, Belfast, where he graduated with honors in July 1971. In the final year of its gathering, 1971-1972, Carson participated in the Belfast group of poets and writers, a gathering of young literary talents organized originally by Philip Hobsbaum at Queens University, Belfast in 1963. After publishing poems in various newspapers and magazines, Carson's first chapbook The Insular Celts appeared in 1973. From 1974-1975 he taught school in Belfast; before joining the Arts Council of Northern Ireland as Traditional Arts Officer in 1976. In 1978, Carson received the Eric Gregory Award for his first book of poems, The New Estate. Three years later he published another chapbook The Lost Explorer (1979). Eight years passed before Carson completed his next volume of poems, The Irish for No (1987), which received the Alice Hunt Bartlett Award. Belfast Confetti (1989), a volume closely related to the 1987 collection, received similar critical success, winning the Irish Times/Aer Lingus prize for poetry.

From 1979 to 1987, Carson continued writing poems and prose pieces including an Appletree Press guide book called Irish Traditional Music, published in 1986. A flutist himself, Carson returned ten years later to a more extensive examination of Irish music with the 1996 publication of the widely heralded Last Night's Fun: About Time, Food and Music. The art of story-telling continued to be a significant aspect of Carson's poetry as seen in First Language, a collection of poems awarded the first T. S. Eliot Prize for the outstanding book of poetry published in Great Britain in 1993. This volume demonstrated Carson's interest in translation including Ovid's Metamorphoses as well as poems written "after" Irish and French originals. 1996 witnessed the publication of Opera Et Cetera, which included a sequence of translations from the Romanian of Stefan Augustin Doinas. Returning to his roots, The Star Factory, Carson's memoir and homage to the Belfast of his childhood followed in 1997.

Leaving the Arts Council in October 1998 to work as a full-time writer, Carson has emerged as one of the major contemporary writers working in English, publishing numerous books of poetry and translations. In 1998, he was appointed a Professor of English at Queenâ€™s University Belfast, where he established the Seamus Heaney Centre for Poetry.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of the personal and literary papers of Ciaran Carson from 1970-2010. The papers include correspondence, literary notebooks, literary manuscripts, printed material, subject files, photographs, and personal files. Among the correspondents represented in the papers are the poets Peter Fallon, Tess Gallagher, Seamus Heaney, Medbh McGuckian, John Montague, and Frank Ormsby. Writings include numerous drafts (in manuscript and typescript form) of Carson's published poems and prose, as well as a significant number of unpublished poems. There are also unpublished draft materials and published versions of creative and critical work sent to or collected by Carson. Printed material includes reviews, programs, and clippings related to Carson's writings, performances and readings. The collection also contains early "group sheets" from Philip Hobsbaum's Belfast Group, Arts Council of Northern Ireland records, and an assortment of photographs and other personal items.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into nine series: (1) Correspondence, (2) Writings by Carson, (3) Writings by others, (4) Printed material by Carson and others, (5) Belfast Group worksheets, (6) Photographs, (7) Personal materials, (8) Subject files, and (9) Arts Council of Northern Ireland records.

separatedmaterial.head: Related Materials in This Repository
separatedmaterial.p: Michael Longley papers, Peter Fallon/Gallery Press collection, and Medbh McGuckian papers.

otherfindaid.head: Finding Aid Note
otherfindaid.p: An index to selected correspondents is available for the correspondence from the mid-1970s to 1999.

did.unittitle: Correspondence, 1971-2010

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The correspondence series contains letters Ciaran Carson received from 1971-2010. A substantial part of the correspondence pertains to letters from Carson's various editors: Peter Fallon at Gallery Press, Dillon Johnston at Wake Forest University Press, and Neil Belton at Jonathan Cape and then Granta. There are also significant literary exchanges with scholars and writers from around the world, including Michael Longley, Seamus Heaney (restricted), Medbh McGuckian, Tim Robinson, Annie Proulx, and Tess Gallagher. The Ciaran Carson / Tess Gallagher correspondence is of particular interest because of the very close attention Gallagher pays to Carson's work at both early and late stages of a volume's development. She has served often as a pre-publication editor of most of Carson's major works, and her often extensive annotations are recorded on many typescripts.
Invitations, contracts, and royalty statements are included in this series and arranged separately from the literary correspondence.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: The correspondence is arranged chronologically. Some correspondence is located with specific writings in Series 2: Writings by Carson.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on access
accessrestrict.p: Special restrictions apply: Series 1, Correspondence, letters by Seamus Heaney are closed to researchers.

otherfindaid.head: Finding Aid Note
otherfindaid.p: An index to selected correspondents is available for the correspondence from the mid-1970s to 1999.

Writings by Carson, circa 1970-2009

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series contains writings by Carson including notebooks, manuscript and typescript drafts of poems and prose, translations, scripts, and interviews from 1970-2009.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into six subseries: (2.1) Notebooks, (2.2) Poetry, (2.3) Translations, (2.4) Prose, (2.5) Scripts for radio and television, and (2.6) Interviews.

did.unittitle: Notebooks, circa 1970-2007

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The notebooks in this series date from the early 1970s to 2007 and include drafts of poems and prose as well as research materials for Carson's published collections during these years. The earliest notebook includes drafts of a variety of poems, some uncollected, from the early 1970's. Early notebooks often contain a diverse array of writings; later ones are dedicated to specific poetry or prose projects. Because there are often several notebooks related to a specific volume, these have been numbered and arranged chronologically in the finding aid.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains manuscript and typescript drafts of poems from 1971-2009. Individual poems are collected by the volume in which they were first published. Folders include manuscript (MS) and/or typescript (TS) versions of the poems. Typescripts and proofs of entire volumes are included at the end of each volume's subsection to roughly demonstrate the chronological development of a published volume. Uncollected poems are filed in a separate subsection. Some poems were originally kept by Carson in folders containing both collected and uncollected manuscripts and typescripts. To assist with the dating of such poems, especially those in the uncollected section, bracketed notes have been added indicating that a particular poem originally was filed by Carson with materials largely pertaining to a specific volume.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into two sections: (2.2a) Collected poems and (2.2b) Uncollected poetry.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains Carson's translations of others' work from 1994-2007. Both poetry and prose are represented here. Stemming from the fact that Irish is Carson's first language, translation is an important feature of Carson's writing life and has become increasingly predominant in Carsonâ€™s writing since 1993. He has translated from Ovid's Latin as well as the Irish of various friends and colleagues. Also, Carson has done translations of contemporary Romanian, and he has worked extensively on nineteenth-century French Symbolist poets. In some cases, translations have been commissioned for other book projects, and when these pieces have also been included in volumes authored by Carson, a note refers to the relevant work in Subseries 2.2 or 2.4. Translations of Carsonâ€™s work can be found in Series 3: Writings by Others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains Carson's prose works from 1985-2009. Materials in this series include research notes, drafts, various corrected typescripts, and proof copies of Carson's fiction and autobiographical writings, creative non-fiction, essays, and reviews. Much of this series is comprised of book-length writings, which document the progression of Carson's blurring of the distinction between a long-lined narrative poetry and lyrical prose. Of particular interest are Carson's non-fiction work about traditional music, Last Night's Fun, and the memoir-like (as well as cinematic) evocation of Belfast, The Star Factory, which influenced Carson's genre-bending books Fishing for Amber and Shamrock Tea. This series contains some unpublished works, which are arranged chronologically with other published works, as well as uncollected essays and reviews, many of which were published in major journals.

Writings by others, 1977-2007

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series contains writings by other authors sent to Carson including writings about Carson and other general works from 1977-2007. Writings include poetry, prose fiction, essays, and reviews and critical readings of Carson's work. Poetry is by various contemporary Irish and American poets and translators, including Tess Gallagher, Eavan Boland, Paul Muldoon, Michael Longley, John Montague, Liam O'Muirthile, and Theo Dorgan. The poetry section also includes some translations of Carson's poems. Prose fiction and drama is predominately by Tess Gallagher. Writings about Carson include reviews, conference papers, and essays by students, journalists, and academics working on Carson's writing. Other writings within this series are essays and dissertations on traditional music, musical scores, essays on history and geography, as well as works of biography or autobiography.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into four subseries: (3.1) Poetry by others, (3.2) Prose fiction and drama by others, (3.3) Writings about Carson, (3.4) Other writings.

did.unittitle: Poetry by others, 1977-2007

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains poetry by others received by Carson from 1977-2007. Much of the collected poetry is related to a special edition of The Back Door, focusing on younger Irish poets. Poets' typescripts gathered for this project are indicated with: [The Back Door]. Correspondence related to this project is in Series 7: Subject files. Carson amassed a number of contributions, but the project never reached fruition. Carson has also received various drafts of poetry from friends and colleagues including Tess Gallagher, Michael Longley, Liam O'Muirthile, and Paul Muldoon. This series also includes translations of Carson's poems by others.

Printed material, 1975-2008

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series contains printed material collected by Carson from 1976-2002. Materials in this series include items by and about Carson, as well as more general, collected material. Printed material by Carson includes various poems, essays, and reviews by Carson, as well as a number of published translations of his work. Of particular interest is an extensive run of essays by Carson from the mid-1980s published in the Belfast Review. Printed material about Carson includes essays and articles about Carson, as well as reviews of his writings. This series also contains promotional material created by Carson's publishers; correspondence, programs, and flyers from Carson's numerous readings and lectures; essays by and about Carson's friends; various journals sent with solicitations for contributions of poetry; several Irish studies journals to which Carson has contributed; photocopies of songs; occasional broadsides; and assorted printed interviews and reviews. One peculiar item is Carson's personal rhyming dictionary used for works up to and including his 2002 translation of Dante's Inferno.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: (4.1) Printed material by Ciaran Carson, (4.2) Printed material about Ciaran Carson, and (4.3) Other printed material.

Belfast Group worksheets, [1971-1972]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series contains worksheets for the Belfast Group from 1971-1972. The Belfast Group, an informal writers' group where the participants read and discussed each other's work, was founded by the poet Philip Hobsbaum in 1963. Hobsbaum stopped his direction of the meetings when he moved back to England in 1966, but Seamus Heaney continued to organize the meetings off and on for the next six years. Early participants included Heaney, Longley, Mahon, James Simmons, and Stewart Parker. Paul Muldoon and Ciaran Carson joined the group in the early 1970s. Typically, one writer's work highlighted a given session. A small selection of poems or, less commonly, a short story would be mimeographed and distributed to participants. These "group sheets" organized by author document the development of both individual writers and a community of writers in Northern Ireland. The Group under Heaney's auspices finally ceased altogether in 1972 at a time of escalating political violence in Northern Ireland. More information about the Belfast Group may be found at http://chaucer.library.emory.edu/irishpoet/index.html.

The Carson papers contain worksheets for the final year of the Belfast Group's existence, 1971-1972. In Carson's papers, these worksheets were gathered together in a folder with various cut-outs of published Carson and Heaney poems (See Subseries 4.1 and 4.3), as well as typescripts of poems found in The Insular Celts and Uncollected Poems. See these poems in Subseries 2.2.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series contains photographs from 1977-2007. Photographs of Carson are mostly during the 1990s, though a number of undated photographs may be from earlier. Many of the photographs are of Carson at readings or formal events. Wherever possible, major literary figures in the photographs have also been identified.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Groups of photographs are alphabetically arranged by principle subject, with individual photographs ordered chronologically when possible.

Arts Council of Northern Ireland records, 1973-1998

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series contains material related to the Arts Council of Northern Ireland from 1973-1985. Materials include grant applications, correspondence, project files, and photographs. Ciaran Carson worked as Traditional Arts Officer for the Arts Council of Northern Ireland (ACNI) from 1976-1998. During his time as Traditional Arts Officer, Carson published his first prose work that examined Irish Traditional Music, an Appletree Press guide book called Irish Traditional Music (1986). He recommenced his public life as a poet with the 1987 publication of The Irish for No, but his interest in and work on behalf of traditional music continued, culminating in his intimate and celebrated consideration of Irish music entitled Last Night's Fun: About Time, Food and Music (1996). Carson resigned from the ACNI in October 1998.

While these Arts Council materials are arranged in four subsections, the folders themselves retain Carson's own system of organization. Thus, in most cases the names of particular folders were originally Carson's. "General Materials" contains documents largely pertaining to financial and other such administrative records. "Projects" contains mostly correspondence between the Arts Council and various groups and individuals involved in the organization of specific cultural events and programs. "Correspondence" collects more general bodies of communication between the Arts Council and those it supports, whether individuals or institutions. The final subsection, "Printed and Other Material" gathers miscellaneous materials such as photos and negatives as well as press clippings.
